Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2017 IEEE International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software (ISPASS-2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software (ISPASS), a premier forum for sharing advanced academic and industrial research focused on performance analysis of computer systems and software, seeks to increase student participation in symposium and the field. The conference will be held from Apr 23, 2017 - Apr 25, 2017 San Francisco Bay Area, California.

The proposed funding would support the travel of up to 15 eligible US students to the symposium. Support from this grant will be distributed to students who may otherwise be unable to attend ISPASS. The grant selection process will give priority to US citizens and permanent residents, with special consideration to members of underrepresented groups and participants from universities that do not have a strong tradition in the ISPASS research domain. Furthermore, support from this grant will also be available to provide companion funding for attendees with disabilities and/or parental responsibility for an infant less than one year old. These efforts are anticipated to broaden the participation in the conference and, by extension, the research field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 International Symposium on Performance Analysis and of Systems and Software was held April 24-25, 2017 in Santa Rosa, CA. This grant provided $10,000 of travel support for students to attend the conference and present their work.

Student travel applications were solicited via the conference website and the email lists of professional organizations. A total of 18 applications were received, of which 12 were from US universities and thus eligible for NSF funding. Priority was given to applicants who were presenting papers or posters; applicants who were US citizens or permanent residents; and applicants who were members of groups underrepresented in computing (including women).  All of the eligible applicants were awarded funding: 12 from this NSF grant, and 6 from additional funds we obtained from the IEEE Computer Society. The NSF awardees represented universities in 7 different states: California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Massachusetts, and Texas.

The ISPASS research field is of great importance to future computer system designs; as the search for increased performance and reduced power consumption becomes more challenging, researchers must understand the performance and power implications of future systems and applications. Travel support for this conference increased participation in the field of performance and power analysis of software and systems and made it possible for students to present their research to the community.  By funding 4 students who are members of underrepresented groups, the award also helped to broaden participation in this field.
